Herein, nickel@nitrogen-doped carbon nanotubes (Ni@NCNTs) are prepared by a simple and reliable method with Ni-based complex as single-source precursor. Significantly, the formation of CNTs is not susceptible to the calcination temperature and ramping rate and Ni@NCNTs can be attained from 430 to 900 °C in an inert atmosphere. Then they are the first time to be applied as the anode material for sodium–ion batteries. The presence of Ni nanoparticles (NPs) facilitates the solid electrolyte interface film over the anode surface and improves the capacity retention of the host material, especially at the high rates. Furthermore, Na+ diffusion is reinforced after the introduction of Ni NPs. Ni@NCNTs obtained at 500 °C (Ni@NCNTs-500) exhibit the best capacity retention and rate capability. Kinetics analyses demonstrate the faster electron transportation and ion diffusion than others prepared at other temperatures. The surficial capacitance storage favors the fast electrochemistry kinetics. It delivers a high specific capacity (192 mA h g−1 at 0.5 A g−1), excellent cycling stability (103 mA h g−1 after 10,000 cycles at 10 A g−1), and outstanding high-rate capability up to 20 A g−1 (118 mA h g −1). The related full cells confirm a high energy density of 140 Wh kg−1 at 38.16 W kg−1 and 44.27 W h kg−1 at 762 W kg−1. Graphical abstract The synthesis of N-doped carbon nanotubes embedded with Ni nanoparticles (Ni@NCNTs) derived from a precursor of one-dimensional rod-shaped Ni(II)-2-methylimidazole complex in a wide range of temperature (430–900 °C) and ramping rate results in fast sodium storage as anode materials for sodium-ion batteries due to their unique structural and compositional features. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Nitrogen-doped carbon nanotubes Ni nanoparticles Anode Sodium-ion batteries 1 Introduction Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) show the fascinating thermal, electronic and mechanical properties and have been attracting a broad range of interests [1]. Moreover, the nitrogen doping can significantly improve the physicochemical properties of CNTs and better the performances, such as the electrical conductivity, oxidation resistance and the stability of metal atoms in metal-carbon nanotube composites. Nitrogen-doped CNTs (NCNTs)-based materials hybridized with various metals can be prepared, and the obtained composites exhibit excellent properties in hydrogen evolution reaction, oxygen evolution reaction, electrocatalytic overall water splitting, electrochemical carbon dioxide reduction, hydrogen storage, secondary lithium ion batteries and so on [2–7]. However, at present, NCNTs are mainly prepared by mixing metal salts and nitrogen-rich organic compounds (NOCs) followed by calcining in an inert atmosphere. Nitrogen-rich organic compounds are largely limited to dicyandiamide, melamine and so on [8]. The main problem of this method is the low utilization of nitrogen-containing organic compounds and thus the low yield of NCNTs, caused by the weak interaction between organic compounds and metal species. Most of the organic compounds evaporate in the calcination process, and only a small part of NOCs transformed into NCNTs under the catalysis effect of metals. Correspondingly, it is an urgent task to explore simple, efficient, reliable and low-cost methods for preparing NCNTs. As a subclass of metal−organic frameworks (MOFs), zeolitic−imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs) have been regarded as remarkable precursors to prepare nitrogen-doped carbonaceous materials due to the presence of abundant nitrogen atoms [9]. Recently, Mai et al. reported the NCNTs prepared from MOF precursors through low temperature pyrolysis (430 °C) in an inert atmosphere, showing excellent catalysis activity in oxidation-reduction reactions (ORR) [10]. Lou et al. reported the preparation of NCNTs by high temperature pyrolysis (≥600 °C) of ZIF-67 in a H2/Ar mixed atmosphere, also offering the remarkable electrocatalytic activity and stability for the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and the oxygen evolution reactions (OER) [11]. Yang's group expounded the synthesis of NCNTs derived from Zn–Fe–MOFs, wherein the ligand molecules of dicyandiamide were used as both the N source and inducer of the carbon nanotube frameworks [12]. However, these methods are either restricted by the heating rate and calcination temperature or the reducing atmosphere. Although a variety of carbon materials have been explored as anode materials of SIBs, a number of them show unsatisfactory electrochemical performance [13,14]. Furthermore, the application of NCNTs embedded with metal nanoparticles has rarely been reported to serve as anode material of sodium–ion batteries (SIBs) to date. As well known, Insertion-type anode materials are superior thanks to the readily reversible insertion/extraction of Na+ ions while they still could maintain the structural integrity [15,16]. Natural graphite, as a traditional anode material of lithium–ion batteries (LIBs), isn't ideal for SIBs due to its small interlayer spacing of 0.34 nm unable to adapt Na+ ions. Thus, a key mission is facing us to explore suitable materials with larger interlayer spacing to accommodate Na+ ions. Recently, a variety of disordered carbon materials have been engineered in term of morphologies, structures and compositions, which have been reported as the anode materials for SIBs due to the adaptability, high electrical conductivity, versatility, and porosity [17–21]. In particular, the heteroatom-doped carbonaceous materials have attracted more attentions, due to the enhancement in electrical conductivity to accelerate the electron transport, the enlargement in specific surface area to increase the binding sites, and the improvement of Na+ adsorbability in the charging process. The availability of N‐doped carbonaceous materials renders the broad investigation of N‐doped carbon fibers, graphene, and carbon nanosheets for the SIB anode materials [22–27]. However, the poor cycling performance and bad rate capability are still persecuting the present carbon anode materials despite the interlayer distance increased [13,14]. Bearing these issues in mind, we here report a simple method for the synthesis of ample N-doped carbon nanotubes embedded with Ni nanoparticles (Ni@NCNTs) derived from a precursor of one-dimensional rod-shaped Ni(II)-2-methylimidazole complex (Ni-2MI). In an inert atmosphere, Ni@NCNTs can be formed over a wide range of calcination temperatures from 430 to 900 °C independent of the heating rate. When the resultant Ni@NCNTs were used as an anode material for SIBs, it exhibited a high reversible capacity of approximately 192 mA h g−1 at 0.5 mA g−1 after 1500 cycles, ultralong cycling stability (103 mA h g−1 for 10,000 cycles at 10 A g−1), and superior rate performance (118.2 mA h g−1 at 20 A g−1). It's the first time to report the application of carbon/Ni composite as the anode materials for SIBs. The excellent electrochemical performance was attributed to the electrochemical catalysis of Ni nanoparticles and the structural features including the suitable nitrogen doping level to favor the fast kinetics of electrochemistry. 2 Experimental 2.1 Material preparation 2.1.1 Synthesis of Ni-2MI precursor The water used in the experiment was ultrapure water (18.25 MΩ) and other chemicals were of analytical grade and used without further purification. In a typical synthesis procedure, 3.02 g of nickel nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, 98%, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent) was dissolved in 41 g of water. 8.54 g of 2-methylimidazole (C4H6N2, 98%, Aladdin Reagent) was dissolved in the same volume of water to the above and then poured into the former solution. The resulting mixture was stirred for 2 h and transferred into a 100 mL Teflon-lined autoclave, followed by treatment at 140 °C for 12 h. After the autoclave naturally cooled to room temperature, yellow solid was obtained by centrifugation, washed with methanol (CH3OH, 99.5%, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent) for four times and dried at 60 °C overnight. 2.1.2 Synthesis of Ni@NCNTs from Ni-2MI precursor The obtained Ni-2MI precursor was pretreated under Argon atmosphere at 150 °C for 2 h to remove adsorbed water and subsequently carbonized at different temperatures (i.e. 430, 500, 700 and 900 °C) for 4 h with a ramp rate of 2 °C min−1. 2.1.3 Synthesis of Na3V2(PO4)3/C The preparation of Na3V2(PO4)3/C was based on the previous report [28]. In a typical process, 1.38 g of NH4H2PO4, 0.728 g of V2O5 and 0.636 g of Na2CO3 were mixed with 100 mL of water and then stirred for 1 h at room temperature. Ascorbic acid (Vc, 1.056 g) and polyethylene glycol-400 (PEG-400, 6 mL) were added to the above solution, and stirred for another 30 min to form a blue suspension, which was transferred to autoclave and kept at 180 °C for 40 h. After cooling to room temperature, the resultant turbid solution was ultrasonicated for half an hour to obtain homogeneous dispersion, and then placed in an oven at 90 °C for 24 h to obtain the brown precipitate. Followed by calcination at 750 °C for 6 h at a heating rate of 3 °C min−1 in Ar atmosphere, the final Na3V2(PO4)3/C sample was obtained. 2.2 Characterizations of material The crystal structure of the products was measured using a Bruker D8 Advance, X-ray powder diffractometer equipped with a Cu K α radiation source with λ = 1.5418 Å. The microstructure and morphology of the products were determined by field-emission scanning microscopy (Gemini SEM 500), transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEOL, JEM-1011) and high-resolution TEM (HRTEM), EELS maps, and HAADF-STEM images (JEOL JEM-ARM 200F field-emission atomic-resolution analytical microscope). CHN elemental analysis was conducted on a Elementar Vario EL Cube CHNS elemental analyzer. FT-IR spectra were obtained on a Bruker ALPHAT FTIR spectrometer. Raman spectra were collected on a NEMUS670 Raman spectrometer with an excitation wavelength of 632 nm at room temperature. The BET surface area and pore size distribution were determined by nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms measurements collected at 77 K using a Micromeritics ASAP-2020HD88 analyzer. The elemental composition and valence on the surface of materials were determined by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo ESCALAB 250Xi). Thermogravimetry analysis was conducted on a Mettler Toledo TGA/SDTA851 thermal analyzer in air with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 from room temperature to 800 °C. 2.3 Electrochemical measurements To prepare the working electrode, 70 wt% of active material (Ni@NCNTs), 20 wt% of conductive agent (acetylene black) and 10 wt% of binder (sodium carboxymethylcellulose, CMC) were mixed together with water as the dispersant to achieve a homogeneous slurry and coated onto Cu foil (Shenzhen BiYuan Electronics with a thickness of 10 µm), dried under vacuum at 60 °C overnight. The average mass loading of each electrode is ~0.9–1.0 mg cm−2. The electrochemical performance was tested using CR2032 coin-type cells with sodium metal as the reference/counter electrode. Whatman GF/D glass fiber was used as the separator, and 1.0 M NaClO4 in ethylene carbonate/diethyl carbonate (EC/DEC, 1/1 v/v) containing 5 wt% fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC) as electrolyte. Galvanostatic charge/discharge cycles were tested using a LAND-CT2001A multichannel galvanostat (Wuhan, China) with the voltage range of 0.005–3.0 V vs. Na+/Na at room temperature. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) behaviors in a potential window of 0.005–3.00 V vs. Na+/Na were performed on an electrochemical workstation (CHI 760E, Shanghai Chen Hua) at room temperature. Electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) were performed in the frequency between 100 kHz and 10 mHz and the amplitude is 5 mV on an electrochemical workstation. For the Na-ion full cells, the cathode was assembled by using homemade Na3V2(PO4)3/C and carbon black mixed together with poly(vinylidene fuoride) (PVDF) as binder in a weight ratio of 8:1:1 coated on an aluminum foil. The capacity ratio of anode/cathode was controlled to be about 1:1.5. Meanwhile, the anode was electrochemically activated for five cycles before it was assembled in full cells. 3 Results and discussion The overall procedure for the synthesis of yellow Ni-2MI complex precursor and the following derivation to Ni@NCNTs is shown in Scheme 1 . Firstly, one-dimensional rod-like Ni-2MI was synthesized by a simple hydrothermal method using nickel nitrate and 2-methylimidazole as the metal source and organic ligand, respectively. As shown in Fig. S1, Ni-2MI exhibits one-dimensional nanorods with a length of approximately 40–100 nm and a width of about 10 nm. As shown in Fig. S2, the XRD pattern of Ni-2MI complex precursor is in agreement with the previously reported XRD pattern of ZIF-67-Ni [29]. The low crystallinity of the Ni-2MI-complex precursor is consistent with the previous reports [29,30] that it is difficult to form an MOF structure when using 2-methylimidazole and Ni2+ as ligand and metal node, respectively. FT-IR spectra analysis of Ni-2MI-complex precursor is conducted to determine the surface functional groups and its molecular structure. As shown in Fig. S3, the FT-IR spectra exhibit bands at 3135 and 2920 cm−1 corresponding to the CH stretch mode from the aliphatic chains in 2-methylimidazole [29,31]. The bands at 1580 and 750 cm−1 should be due to the bending mode and stretching vibration of the C=N bonds in 2-methylimidazole [32,33]. The intense peaks between 1500 and 1000 cm−1 are attributed to the skeletal vibration of the imidazole ring [33]. The band at around 412 cm−1 should be ascribed to the Ni−N stretch indicating the formation of coordination polymer [29,34]. In order to identify the chemical composition of the Ni-2MI complex precursor, CHN elemental analysis and oxidation treatment of Ni-2MI were done. The obtained results (Table S1 and Fig. S4) indicated that the molar composition of the Ni-2MI precursor is NiN4.25C8.55H12.04. Then, the Ni-2MI precursor was carbonized and worked as the self-sacrifice template in an argon atmosphere to obtain Ni@NCNTs composites. As can be seen from Fig. 1 and Figs. S5−S7, even in a wide temperature range of 430–900 °C, the CNTs can be formed via the calcination of Ni-2MI and named as Ni@NCNTs-430, Ni@NCNTs-700 and Ni@NCNTs-900. It's clear to observe the formation of CNTs and the irregular bulk solid on the rough surface by calcination of the Ni-2MI. Obviously, the formation of Ni@NCNTs is not sensitive to the calcination temperature. Fig. 1(a) shows the panoramic view of Ni@NCNTs-500 obtained at 500 °C, showing some fluffy structures. The detailed microstructure and texture were further investigated. Some aggregates are present in the vision with nanoparticles embedded and the CNTs clearly form in Fig. 1(b)–(d). The tubelike structure with an average outer diameter of ~10.9 nm is obviously observable. The inner hollow channel exhibits a diameter of 3.5 nm with the wall thickness of ~3.7 nm. The high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) images in Fig. 1(e)–(i) indicate the remarkable lattice stacking a token of multiwall CNTs and the adjacent interlayer distance of ~0.38 nm, which is much larger than that of natural graphite (d 002 = 0.34 nm). It is worth noting that the oriented multilayer twisted wrinkles of graphitic layers in the CNT walls are not keeping perfect pace with the axis direction of the CNTs. Such structure will contribute to the abundant edges exposed on the surface of nanotube, which would be good for enhanced electrochemistry properties [35]. Moreover, Ni nanoparticles are revealed to be at the tip of nanotubes and encapsulated by carbon layer (Fig. 1(f)). Simultaneously, the Ni nanoparticles in the aggregate are described in Fig. 1(h). And the magnified image in Fig. 1(i) exhibits the graphene-layer coating on the particles. The well-defined lattice fringes of Ni nanoparticles exceptionally demonstrate the good crystallinity and the interspacing of 0.20 nm corresponds to the (111) crystal plane of cubic Ni phase. As shown in Fig. S8, there still are residual nickel nanoparticles at the end of NCNTs even after acid leaching, further demonstrating the encapsulation by carbon layer. These Ni nanoparticles are deemed to be inaccessible to the electrochemical reactions due to the complete encapsulation within the graphene-like carbon layer. The composition and phase structure of the Ni@NCNTs were further investigated by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) (Fig. 2(a)). The peak is observed at ~26.2°, corresponding to the (002) diffraction of graphite, and other characteristic peaks at about 44.3°, 51.6°, and 76.2° are attributed to (111), (200), and (220) lattice planes of cubic Ni, respectively. Raman spectra of the products contain the characteristic G (sp 2-bonded pairs) and D (sp 3 defects induced disordering) bands at approximately 1580 and 1330 cm−1 [36–38], respectively (Fig. 2(b)). The peak intensity ratio (I G/I D) value was used to evaluate the degree of graphitization. Notably, the value of I G/I D increases with the increase of calcination temperature (Table 1 ) from 0.89, 0.93, 0.94 to 0.98, attributed to the increased degree of graphitization initiated by the higher temperature [39]. The surface chemical composition and the synergy of nitrogen doping and nickel nanoparticles are further investigated by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The survey spectra in Fig. 2(c) show that Ni@NCNTs are composed of C, N, O and Ni, with the N contents to be 21.8%, 20.9%, 13.9% and 5.73% (at%) for Ni@NCNTs-430, Ni@NCNTs-500, Ni@NCNTs-700 and Ni@NCNTs-900, respectively. The N content decreases with the carbonization temperature increasing [40]. The high-resolution N 1s spectra in Fig. 2(d) can be divided into three peaks, including pyridinic N (398.5 eV), pyrrolic N (400.0 eV), and graphitic N (401 eV). It is exciting that the N content of Ni@NCNTs-500 is higher than most N-doping carbon materials previously reported [2,3]. It is well-established that pyridinic and pyrrolic N atoms can serve as electrochemically active sites and introduce additional defects in the carbon lattice, which are expected to enhance the capacity by reversibly binding with the charge carriers and improve the fast diffusion for SIBs [41]. The C 1s spectra (Fig. S9a) include two characteristic bands, corresponding to C–C and C=N bonds at about 284.5 and 285.6 eV, respectively [42]. The Ni 2p spectrum (Fig. S9b) can be deconvoluted into two bands corresponding to Ni 2p 3/2 and Ni 2p 1/2, with the respective satellite peaks at 862.6 and 881.3 eV [43,44]. One couple of peaks centered at 855.5 and 872.8 eV is from Ni2+ species caused by oxidation of the surface. Another couple centered at 852.6 and 869.8 eV is assignable to metallic Ni(0) [43,44]. According to the obtained results of CHN elemental analysis (Table 1) and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA, Fig. 2(e)), with the increase of pyrolysis temperature, the carbon and nickel contents both show a gradually increasing trend. The porous texture of Ni@NCNTs was investigated using N2-adsorption/desorption. Fig. 2(f) shows the similar sorption behaviors confirmed as the type-IV isotherms with H3 hysteresis loops, indicating a mesoporous structure. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface areas of Ni@NCNTs-430, −500, −700 and −900 were calculated to be 415.2, 383.9, 364.8, and 294.4 m2 g–1, respectively. It indicates that the surface area gradually decreases with the increase of carbonization temperature. The inset image is the corresponding pore size distribution curves based on the BJH method. The pores are mainly distributed in the range of smaller than 10 nm and formed by the carbonization of the ligand molecules. The minor pores are larger than 10 nm, mainly due to the hollow interior of nanotubes. The mesopores could raise the contact area between the electrode and electrolyte and shorten diffusion distance of Na+ ions, resulting in the enhanced charging/discharging performance of the NCNTs. During the calcination process, the metallic Ni nanoparticles play a key role in the formation of porous carbon nanotube frameworks. In an inert gas, the organic carbon source has the reducibility in the process of conversion to carbon. Ni2+ ions in the MOF were correspondingly reduced to metal Ni particles, which worked as the catalyst for the growth of CNTs like other single metals or bimetals like Fe, Mo, bimetallic Fe–Mo or Co–Mo [10,45,46]. In the formation process of CNTs, Ni-2MI precursor was employed not only as the C and N sources, but also as the self-sacrificial template for growth of CNTs with the aid of metallic Ni catalysts. In order to further demonstrate the reliability and workability of the method, Ni-2MI precursor was calcined at different calcination temperatures under different heating rates. As shown in the FESEM and TEM results (Figs. S10−S12), remarkable CNT structures dominate the products no matter the heating rate is 2, 5 and 10 °C min–1 at 500, 700 and 900 °C, respectively. It's fully confirmed that Ni@NCNTs can be successfully prepared by the present method proposed herein. Different from the methods already reported in the literature, our work has successfully realized the preparation of NCNT structures by simple pyrolysis of a single Ni-2MI precursor in inert atmosphere in a wide temperature range without being affected by the heating rate. The Ni@NCNTs were used as the anode material for SIBs and tested at the voltage range of 0.005−3.00 V (vs Na+/Na). All the specific capacities in this work were calculated based on the mass of the active material (Ni@NCNTs) unless annotated else. The effect of Ni nanoparticles and N content in the carbon nanotubes had a great influence on the enhanced electrochemical performance of SIBs. Fig. 3 (a) shows the initial several cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves of the Ni@NCNTs-500 hybrid electrode in the potential window between 0.005 and 3.0 V at the scan rate of 0.1 mV s−1. The CV curve of the 1st cycle for Ni@NCNTs-500 is obviously different from the followed cycles. A strong and broad reduction peak is at about 1.25 V and disappears in the following scans. Here, despite that Ni nanocrystals are electrochemically inert to directly react with Na+, the decomposition reactions of electrolytes are initiated to form the solid–electrolyte interphase (SEI) via the catalysis of Ni and contribute to the capacity [42]. So the peak at ~1.25 V can be attributed to the preliminary decomposition of electrolytes and the formation of SEI films. It can be further proved by the CV curves of NCNTs-500 obtained after Ni@NCNTs-500 was acid-treated to remove Ni nanoparticles. It is obvious that the peak is invisible to be noted (Fig. S13). Another weak reduction peak at low potential of ~0.86 V is observed, which can be assigned to the continuous formation of SEI layer from a known viewpoint [47–49]. Notably, the CV curves overlap well after the first cycle, indicating the good cyclability and stability of the material for the insertion/extraction process of Na+ ions. Obviously, Ni@NCNTs-500 exhibits the similar profile of CV curves to Ni@NCNTs-700 and Ni@NCNTs-900 (Fig. S14), indicating the similar reaction mechanism for electrochemical storage. To shed more light on the effect of metallic Ni on the electrochemistry of Na+ storage, more comparative analyses were carried out via the galvanostatic intermittent titration (GITT) technique in Fig. S15. It can be observed that Ni@NCNTs-500 has lower reaction resistance and higher Na+ diffusion coefficient (D Na+) than NCNTs-500 during the charge/discharge process (Figs. S16 and S17). Ni nanoparticles are inert to react with Na+ and contribute nothing to sodium storage. However, Ni@NCNTs exhibit much higher reversible capacities than the NCNTs. One possible explanation for the high capacity is that Ni nanoparticles can effectively catalyze the sodium−nitrogen reactions. Transition-metal nitrides, such as Fe3N, Co3N and CoN, can reversibly form metal nanoparticles and Na3N along with considerable sodium storage capacity. During this process, the electrons were transferred only between high-valence M and metallic M(0), whereas N3− was stable in the whole cycle. The formed metal nanoparticles can serve as efficient catalysts to activate/promote the reversible formation and decomposition of some SEI components, especially Na2CO3 [50–52]. C4+ in Na2CO3 can be reversibly reduced to other C species with low valences and simultaneously store considerable energy [53]. In our work, Ni nanoparticles exhibited no phase change during either discharge or charge process, demonstrated by the ex-situ XRD patterns of the Ni@NCNTs electrode in Fig. S18. Therefore, the electrochemical capacity of Ni@NCNTs nanotubes should be ascribed to the inter/decalation reactions of C other than Ni. In this work, Ni nanoparticles in Ni@NCNTs nanotubes should have a similar catalytic effect to the previous reports mentioned. It functioned as effective catalysts to activate/promote the electrochemical conversion of some components in SEI films. In fact, the reversible redox reactions of SEI components have also widely been noticed in the extra capacity phenomena of transition-metal oxides (including NiO) [53,54]. It is clear that NCNTs-500 exhibits the lower discharge capacity than Ni@NCNTs-500 in spite of electrochemically inert Ni present, especially at higher rates (Figs. S19 and S20). Fig. 3(b) shows the galvanostatic charge/discharge curves of the Ni@NCNTs-500 electrode at the current density of 0.2 mA g−1. An obvious voltage platform between 1.0 and 1.5 V followed by a long tail extending to the cut-off voltage of 0.005 V can be found in the first discharge, in agreement with the CV results. From other curves at 10th, 100th and 500th cycle, the prominent sloping features without distinct plateau rightly demonstrate the dominant capacitive behaviors [54]. The similar cycling curves of Ni@NCNTs-430, −700 and −900 are present in Fig. S19, further testifying the analogous storage mechanism. The characteristic sloping is a typical characteristic of Na+ insertion into the interlayer spacing [55]. In Fig. S21, at the current density of 0.2 A g−1, Ni@NCNTs-500 presents the initial discharge/charge capacities of 1015 and 300 mA h g−1 with the initial coulombic efficiency (ICE) of 29.6%. While only 941.8 and 282.8 mA h g–1 with ICE of 30.0% are for Ni@NCNTs-430, 996.1 and 227.1 mA h g–1 with ICE of 22.8% are for Ni@NCNTs-700, and 1010.6 and 207.9 mA h g–1 with ICE of 20.6% are for Ni@NCNTs-900, exhibiting the low initial coulomb efficiency (ICE). It's a common and unpleasant problem of carbon-based anode materials for LIBs and SIBs based on the ester electrolyte [56]. The large irreversible capacity is largely caused by the formation of solid electrolyte interface (SEI) film and the decomposition of electrolyte [57,58]. Notably, the CE can reach up to 99% after five cycles for all the Ni@NCNTs electrodes. Ni@NCNTs-500 delivers a reversible capacity of 253.6 mA h g−1 after 300 cycles, versus 201, 162.7 and 129.5 mA h g–1 for Ni@NCNTs-430, Ni@NCNTs-700 and Ni@NCNTs-900, respectively. The rate capability at different current densities has been explored for these electrodes in Fig. 3(c), where the Ni@NCNTs-500 shows the best rate capability. It delivers the discharge capacities of 287.8, 234.9, 204.6, 169.5 and 132.4 mA h g−1 at various current densities of 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2 and 5 A g−1, respectively. Notably, even at so high rate of 10 and 20 A g–1, the reversible capacities of 120.8 and 118.2 mA h g–1 are retained, respectively. Moreover, when the current density suddenly returns back to 0.5 A g–1, the discharge capacity still recovers to a stable capacity of 255.8 mA h g–1. As comparison, Ni@NCNTs-430, −700 and −900 deliver lower capacities than Ni@NCNTs-500 at each current interval. Additionally, these Ni@NCNTs samples were also investigated at the current densities of 0.5, 1 and 2 A g−1 to testify the long-term cyclability. Before the aimed current density, all the Ni@NCNTs electrodes were tested firstly at 0.2 A g–1 for 5 cycles to activate. As expected, Ni@NCNTs-500 exhibits excellent long-term cycling stability by retaining capacities of 192, 190, and 160 mA h g–1 at the current densities of 0.5, 1 and 2 A g−1 after 1500, 2000, and 5000 cycles, respectively (Fig. 3(d)−(f)). Even at 10 A g–1, Ni@NCNTs-500 electrode can retain 103 mA h g–1 after 10,000 cycles (Fig. 3(g)). The performance of Ni@NCNTs is evaluated by comparison with other related reports about carbon materials as anode materials of SIBs in Table S1, displaying the superior electrochemistry behaviors. The Ni@NCNT-500 showed the better electrochemical performance than the other samples. Ni@NCNT-700 and −900 were obtained at higher temperature, showing lower capacities than Ni@NCNT-500 due to the low N doping in the analogous graphene structures and the high Ni content. As an indispensable aspect, carbon nanotubes provide beneficial space for well-distributed formation of SEI films and subsequent electrochemical conversion reactions. Besides, metallic Ni nanoparticles could improve the electronic conductivity of the whole electrode and catalyze the SEI formation to improve the capacity of sodium storage. Therefore, there should be a balance between the contents of Ni nanoparticles and carbon nanotubes in samples. Moreover, higher carbonization temperatures facilitate the formation of quaternary N based on the XPS results. The high quaternary N content in the lattice can increase the energy of the carbon framework. The structural instability would increase after many charge–discharge cycles [59]. Hence, it suggests that the high quaternary N content in Ni@NCNT-700 (21.86%) results in the bad cycling performance. Although the Ni@NCNT-430 has a greater N content than the Ni@NCNT-500, the electrochemical performance of Ni@NCNT-430 is poorer than that of Ni@NCNT-500. The difference can be attributed to the low temperature, which is not optimal for the direct carbonization of precursor. In this case, some N atoms exist as CN groups in Ni@NCNT-430, which is not beneficial for Na+ storage. The high edge-nitrogen contents of carbon nanotube in-between the analogy graphene layers could act as flavoring agent, not only enhancing the adsorption energy of Na+ to the electrode materials, but also providing more active sites for the soakage of electrolyte ions [60,61]. Relying on the structural features including suitable Ni content, high doping nitrogen and relative edge nitrogen content (Table 1), Ni@NCNT-500 showed the better electrochemical performance than the other samples. To dig out more fundamentals of excellent long-term cycling stability and high-rate performance of the Ni@NCNTs-500 electrode, the quantitative analyses of charge storage have been carried out. The electrochemical kinetics of the electrodes were investigated via CV measurements at sweep rates from 0.2 to 10 mV s–1 (Fig. 4(a)–(c)). For Ni@NCNTs-500 electrode in Fig. 4(a), the broad oxidation peaks are still remained and the peak shifts toward to high potential under high sweep rates can be clearly seen. By contrast, the integral area of CV curves for Ni@NCNTs-500 are larger than Ni@NCNTs-700 and Ni@NCNTs-900 (Fig. 4(b) and (c)), implying the higher reversible capacity of electrochemical reactions. The capacitive effect can be qualitatively analyzed by power law relationship with the scan rate, according to Eq. (1) [62,63]: i = a v b log ( i ) = b × log ( v ) + log ( a ) Where i represents peak current, ν is scan rate, a and b are constants. The b value can be obtained by calculating the slope of log (i) vs log (ν) curves. Typically, if the b value is 0.5, an ideal faradaic intercalation process is dominated (diffusion controlled intercalation process), whereas b value is close to 1, indicating a surface charge storage process (capacitive process) [64,65] The linear relationship of three electrodes can be seen in Fig. 4(d). b is as high as 0.90 for Ni@NCNTs-500, indicating the fast kinetics dominated by a surface-induced process. As contrast, b value decreases to 0.84 and 0.83 for Ni@NCNTs-700 and Ni@NCNTs-900, respectively. The total charge storage can be can be further quantitatively differentiated at a given sweep scan, including the capacitive and diffusion-controlled charge by Eq. (2) [66] i = k 1 v + k 2 v 1 / 2 i / v 1 / 2 = k 1 v 1 / 2 + k 2 By determining the k 1 and k 2 constants, the capacity fraction of two processes can be distinguished. As shown in Fig. 4(f)–(h), 85% of the total charge is contributed by the surface process (red region) at a scan rate of 5 mV s–1 for Ni@NCNTs-500, much higher than that of Ni@NCNTs-700 (75%) and Ni@NCNTs-900 (65%). The capacity contribution ratios of the two processes at different scan rates can also be determined by similar analyses in Fig. 4(e). It is obviously to conclude that the surficial capacitance contribution gradually increases with higher scan rates for all Ni@NCNTs. However, the capacitance contribution decreases as the temperature increases at each scan rate and in keeping with the order of N-doping level, which could be attributed to that more N dopant into the carbon lattice could induce more active sites leading to fast kinetics to improve the sodium-ion storage [61]. As a result, the higher capacitive contribution enhances the rate performance of the Ni@NCNTs-500 electrode. To better understand the excellent electrochemical performance of Ni@NCNTs-500 from a kinetic viewpoint, GITT technique was used to explore the Na-ion diffusion coefficient (D Na) during different charge/discharge levels in Ni@NCNTs samples [67]. Fig. 5 (a) shows the potential response of electrodes and the short dot curve is the equilibrium open-circuit voltages (OCVs) during GITT measurement. The difference of the potential at the end of the current step and the relaxation step represents overpotential (∆E) at different state. As shown in Fig. 5(a), for the discharge process, the ∆E for all both electrodes are initially stable but followed by the slow decrease with discharge process proceeding. On the contrary, ∆E values increase fast during the following charging step. The reaction resistances at different Na+ storage levels are deduced via dividing the overpotential by the constant pulse current density. For the Na+ insertion process (Fig. 5(b)), the reaction resistances for both electrodes gradually decrease as the electrochemical reaction progresses. For the Na+ extraction process (Fig. 5(c)), it is stable at the beginning of reaction and then rapidly rises. Clearly, during the Na+ insertion/extraction process, the Ni@NCNTs-500 has the smallest reaction resistances, consistent with electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) results (Fig. 5(f)). This is a good evidence for Ni@NCNTs-500 to possess faster Na+ insertion/extraction kinetics than Ni@NCNTs-700 and Ni@NCNTs-900. The D Na as a function of potential is calculated by the Fick's second law in the following equation [68]: D = 4 π τ ( m B V M M B S ) 2 ( Δ E S / Δ E τ ) 2 where, τ represents the duration of the current pulse (s), S is the surface area of the electrode, M B/V M is the gravimetric density of host carbon, which is about 1.6 g cm−3 according to the Archimedes’ method (ASTM C-373-88). The relationship of ΔE S and ΔEτ in this equation was learned from literature previously reported [69]. As we can see from Fig. 5(d) and (e), Ni@NCNTs-500 exhibits the higher D Na during the Na+ insertion and extraction process. That's to say, Na-ion diffusion in the Ni@NCNTs-500 electrode is much faster than that of Ni@NCNTs-700 and Ni@NCNTs-900, attributing to more active sites derived from nitrogen doping and electrochemical catalysis of Ni nanoparticles anchored in the CNTs. Based on the above kinetics analyses, the Ni@NCNTs-500 electrode offers the rapid electron and ion transportation during repeated charge/discharge process. Furthermore, the surface-initiated capacitance renders the advantageous charge transfer, contributing to a remarkable electrochemical performance especially at the high rates. To further confirm the potential application of Ni@NCNTs, the related full cells were assembled with the Ni@NCNTs-500 as the SIBs anode material and the homemade Na3V2(PO4)3/C (NVP/C) was employed as the cathode material. The morphology and phase structure of Na3V2(PO4)3/C were explored, which have been shown in Fig. S22 (a and b). Before that, the homemade Na3V2(PO4)3/C was first assembled half-cell and tested, which has shown a stable reversible capacity about 90 mA h g−1 at a current density of 200 mA g−1 after 200 cycles (Fig. S22c). As shown in Fig. 6 (a), in the voltage window between 1.0 and 3.9 V vs Na+/Na, the reversible capacity could still be stabilized at 276 mA h ganode −1 (the capacity calculated based on the mass of anode material) after 120 cycles at the current density of 0.2 A g−1. The rate performance in Fig. 6(b) displays a capacity of 203.2, 142.1, 100.5, 76.3, and 59.3 mA h ganode −1 at the current densities of 0.05, 0.1, 0.2, 0.5 and 1 A g−1, respectively. Fig. 6(c) shows the corresponding discharge/charge profile of the full cells at different current densities. The Ragone plot in Fig. 6(d) displays a high energy density of 140 Wh kgtotal −1 at 38.16 W kgtotal −1 and 44.265 W h kgtotal −1 at 762 W kgtotal −1. It should be pointed out that the electrochemistry performances would be better, if the ratio of NVP/C to Ni@NCNTs is optimized or more appropriate cathode materials are applied. 4 Conclusions In summary, a facile method was conceived to synthesize N-doped carbon nanotubes embedded with Ni nanoparticles (Ni@NCNTs) derived from Ni-2MI complex precursor. Due to the low susceptivity to the transformation conditions, Ni@NCNTs can be successfully attained in a wide temperature range of 430−900 °C at an arbitrary ramping rate of 2−10 °C min−1. The CNTs formed relying on the catalytic role of the as-generated Ni nanoparticles. In the electrochemical Na storage process, by means of the catalytic ability of metallic Ni, the decomposition/formation reactions of electrolytes happen to stabilize the SEI film. Moreover, nitrogen doping in carbon lattice could induce more surface defects and edges that lead to fast kinetics and improve Na-ion adsorption and reservation. From the viewpoint of structure, the unique one-dimensional nanotubes could provide good conductive network for charge carriers. The capacitance process mechanism is dominating the charge storage, rendering the fast electrochemical reactions and the rate capability. The work demonstrates that Ni@NCNTs electrode has a great potential to be used in SIBs, in view of the superior rate capability and cyclability. Moreover, the relevant full cells with Ni@NCNTs as anode offer good capacity retention. Based on the method proposed herein, various derivatives, such as NiS x @NCNTs, NiP x @NCNTs and NiSe x @ NCNTs, can be obtained and the related researches are in progress. coredata.dc:description: Herein, nickel@nitrogen-doped carbon nanotubes (Ni@NCNTs) are prepared by a simple and reliable method with Ni-based complex as single-source precursor. Significantly, the formation of CNTs is not susceptible to the calcination temperature and ramping rate and Ni@NCNTs can be attained from 430 to 900 °C in an inert atmosphere. Then they are the first time to be applied as the anode material for sodium–ion batteries. The presence of Ni nanoparticles (NPs) facilitates the solid electrolyte interface film over the anode surface and improves the capacity retention of the host material, especially at the high rates. Furthermore, Na+ diffusion is reinforced after the introduction of Ni NPs. Ni@NCNTs obtained at 500 °C (Ni@NCNTs-500) exhibit the best capacity retention and rate capability. Kinetics analyses demonstrate the faster electron transportation and ion diffusion than others prepared at other temperatures. The surficial capacitance storage favors the fast electrochemistry kinetics. It delivers a high specific capacity (192 mA h g−1 at 0.5 A g−1), excellent cycling stability (103 mA h g−1 after 10,000 cycles at 10 A g−1), and outstanding high-rate capability up to 20 A g−1 (118 mA h g −1). The related full cells confirm a high energy density of 140 Wh kg−1 at 38.16 W kg−1 and 44.27 W h kg−1 at 762 W kg−1.
